Dear Dr. Moss:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
Description service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(d) Storage of medications.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Medication is not being stored properly, allowing a youth to break
in and take it in an attempt to overdose.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed on 01/24/2024 and did not
provide any additional information.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed on 01/24/2024 during a
previously announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He showed
mounted first aid kits throughout the facility, which were metal
boxes with dual clasped doors on them. The Chief Administrator
also showed where each incident had occurred that involved
Youth A ingesting Tylenol during escalated incidents. He
confirmed he did not witness the parts of the incidents where
Youth A was able to obtain over-the-counter medication and
ingest it, but he was present for other parts of the incidents. The
first instance occurred inside of the clinical area of the facility. The
entrance to the clinical area is locked, and within it is a seating
area and then a hallway with offices for therapists and nurses. At
the end of the hallway there was a metal first aid kit box mounted
on the wall. At the time of this visit that first aid kit was secured by
zip ties. When opened, there were only a few items of gauze and
medical tape located within. The Chief Administrator showed a
separate locked closet within this suite that contained over-the-
counter medications and treatments at that time. The second
instance of Youth A getting access to Tylenol occurred in multiple
areas of the facility. It started near the entrance of a gym and the
adjoining hallway, where there is another wall mounted first aid kit.
This was the one location where Youth A allegedly obtained over-
the-counter medication during this incident. The Chief
Administrator stated Youth A was then brought to a classroom
located outside of his unit for further supervision.
2

Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 02/21/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He
confirmed there had been two separate occasions where he had
been able to get over-the counter medication in his possession.
During the first incident, Youth A stated he was in the clinical area
of the facility. Youth A recalled Case Manager 1 and Therapist 1
were present and trying to de-escalate him as he was getting
increasingly upset. Youth A stated he was “playing games with
them” as he ran around the clinical office area. Youth A
eventually went up to a metal boxed first aid kit mounted on the
wall and opened it. He stated this was not locked at the time.
Youth A recalled taking a box of individually packaged Tylenol and
grabbing a handful of them and then ran away from staff. Youth A
recalled trying to rip a bunch of the packs open and take the
medication. He initially stated he had taken 30 pills, but further in
the interview he stated it was probably more like ten. Youth A
stated he was quickly taken to the hospital after this occurred for
medical attention. He could not specifically recall when this
occurred. Youth A recalled a separate incident where he was able
to do the same thing a few weeks later. He stated he was in a
hallway of the facility and was getting mad when he attempted to
do the same thing as a few weeks prior. Youth A recalled finding
another wall mounted first aid kit and this time it was secured with
zip ties. He stated he was able to break this kit open through the
zip ties before any staff were able to approach him. Youth A then
recalled he turned the lights off in the hallway as he did this,
grabbed more individual Tylenol packets, and then put them in his
pants pocket. Youth A stated he then went into the gym and tried
to take the pills while drinking some Gatorade he had in his
pocket. He recalled a staff member being right there with him and
trying to stop him. Youth A also recalled this indeterminate staff
member stating “It’s not gonna do nothing” because Youth A took
three to five pills. Youth A recalled other staff, that he could not
remember, escorting him to a nearby classroom, and he was
transported to the hospital for medical attention not long after that.
Youth A stated he attempted to open and ingest some staples that
were in a teacher’s desk in that classroom. Youth A believed no
other youth witnessed either incident because he was the only
youth in the clinical area during the first incident and he had been
wandering the hallways with staff following him during the second
instance.
Nurse 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 02/21/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She
recalled being a part of both incidents with Youth A. Nurse 1
3

stated she did not see Youth A ingest the Tylenol during the first
incident, but she did see the wrappers from what Youth A had
grabbed on the floor when she entered the clinical area. Nurse 1
recalled Case Manager 1 and Staff 1 were present. Nurse 1
stated Staff 1 performed the Heimlich maneuver on Youth A and
this was successful. Nurse 1 stated she then quickly arranged for
Youth A to be taken to the hospital. Nurse 1 also recalled being a
part of the second incident in a similar manner, reporting to the
classroom where Youth A was after he had taken the Tylenol.
She recalled several other staff present that she could not name.
Nurse 1 recalled seeing Youth A attempt to ingest staples only for
staff members to get the staples out of his hand to prevent this.
Nurse 1 stated 911 was called and Youth A was quickly taken to
the hospital.
Staff 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 02/21/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He recalled
being involved with the first incident of Youth A ingesting Tylenol.
He stated he was in the clinical area with Youth A and that Youth
A had been struggling emotionally for about an hour. Staff 1
stated he was within arm’s reach of Youth A when Youth A
opened a wall mounted first aid kit and appeared to grab anything
that was inside of it. Staff 1 recalled Youth A having a handful of
individually wrapped Tylenol packets. Staff 1 stated he was trying
to verbally de-escalate Youth A and grab the packets from him
when Youth A quickly ripped some open and dumped some of the
pills in his mouth. Staff 1 recalled immediately performing the
Heimlich maneuver and this was successful as several pills came
out of Youth A’s mouth. Staff 1 was not sure if Youth A swallowed
any of the pills. Staff 1 believed he was the assigned 1:1 staff for
Youth A at that time. He confirmed he never lost line of sight for
Youth A and he stated he was engaged with him during the entire
incident.
Staff 2 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 02/21/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated
he was a part of the second incident of Youth A taking Tylenol in
an unapproved manner. He saw Youth A come out of the gym
into the hallway and Staff 2 witnessed him stuffing something in
his mouth. Staff 2 stated he was close enough to Youth A to pick
some of the pills out of his mouth before any could be swallowed.
Staff 2 also recalled Youth A spitting some of the pills out of his
mouth. He stated he was not certain what Youth A ingested other
than recognizing them as pills in individual wrappers, but that is
what prompted him to attempt to get them out of Youth A’s mouth.
Staff 2 believed this occurred near the mounted first aid kit on the
4

wall. Staff 2 had not seen Youth A break in to this but assumed
that was what occurred because it had been broken open.
Nurse 2 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 02/21/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated
that she was involved in the first instance of Youth A ingesting
Tylenol, but she did not witness him doing so. Nurse 2 recalled
Youth A was escalated to the point of attempting to grab and
ingest almost anything he could get his hands on within the clinical
area, including examination gloves and post-it notes.
Therapist 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on 02/21/2024
during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility. She stated
she witnessed Youth A in the classroom after he attempted to
ingest Tylenol during that second instance. Therapist 1 recalled
approximately five staff members in the room with her and Youth
A but could not recall exactly who those staff were. She
attempted to speak with Youth A but he was not very responsive
at that moment. Therapist 1 recalled attempted restraints
occurring because Youth A was trying to grab anything he could,
including staples from a teacher’s desk, to ingest. Therapist 1 did
not see staples get ingested and was not sure if Youth A was able
to do so. Therapist 1 stated she was with Youth A until he was
transported to the hospital.
Case Manager 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 on
02/21/2024 during an announced, face-to-face visit to the facility.
She recalled being present for both instances of Youth A ingesting
Tylenol. For the first incident she recalled being in the clinical
area with Staff 1 and Youth A as they were conversing with him.
Youth A became more and more escalated, and Case Manager 1
saw him go past Staff 1 and up to a wall mounted first aid kit.
Case Manager 1 saw Youth A open this first aid kit and noted that
it was not locked in any form. She recalled Youth A grabbing
whatever he could and doing so quickly, including Tylenol
packets. Case Manager 1 recalled Youth A then running past
both staff members back down the same hallway where they were
standing and as he did so he put several of the packets in his
mouth. Case Manager 1 was not sure how many pills Youth A
ingested. She recalled telling Staff 1 to do the Heimlich maneuver
and he did, with it resulting in Youth A regurgitating several pills.
Case Manager 1 recalled Youth A quickly de-escalating at that
point and then being transported to the hospital for further
attention. Case Manager 1 then recalled the second incident
where Youth A ingested Tylenol. She stated she was not in front
of Youth A when he first ingested Tylenol, but she did see pills in
5

his mouth as he turned around. She believed Staff 3 was the staff
member that was providing the closest supervision of Youth A at
that point in time. Case Manager 1 recalled telling Staff 3 to
perform the Heimlich maneuver and he did, but it was not as
successful as the first instance in that they believed Youth A
swallowed some of the pills. Case Manager 1 recalled Youth A
then calming down and eventually going to the hospital.
The facility was toured with the Chief Administrator on
02/21/2024. Each wall mounted first aid kit was viewed and it was
confirmed they were empty and not of use anymore. The Chief
Administrator showed a new setup where a locked closet inside of
the locked clinical area was being utilized for the storage of all
over-the counter medications and other related first aid and topical
care items.
Staff 3 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 over the phone on
02/23/2024. He stated he was involved in both situations where
Youth A took Tylenol. Staff 3 clarified that he only met with other
staff after the first instance where Youth A took Tylenol. When
Staff 3 came into the clinical office he recalled Youth A stating,
“I’ve been taking medicine” and also stating that he was starting to
feel dizzy. Staff 3 recalled Nurse 1, Case Manager 1 and
Therapist 1 being present already. Staff 3 stated he accompanied
Youth A to the hospital without incident, and he was able to get
attention and be released quickly. Staff 3 stated he was also
involved in the second incident, but again after Youth A ingested
Tylenol. Staff 3 recalled attempting to put Youth A in a standing
hold restraint as Youth A was trying to ingest either staples or an
examination glove, but he did not need to complete the restraint
hold as Youth A dropped the item.
During a phone call held on 04/05/2024 DHHS Worker 1 stated
they would not have findings resulting from their investigation.
Documents reviewed:
• Incident reports (IR) for both instances involving Youth A
were provided:
o The first incident was dated 01/16/2024 and the IR
provides details consistent with interviews of youth
and staff.
o The second incident was dated 02/05/2024 and the
IR provides details consistent with interviews of
youth and staff.
• Video footage was provided, but in both cases the footage
proved to be inconclusive to the events that occurred. On
6

02/27/2024 the Chief Administrator stated that the video
footage inside of the clinical area during the first incident
was not able to be located due to a technical issue. Two
camera angles containing video footage of the second
incident on 02/05/2024 were provided. The first is
obscured, and the second does not provide a clear view of
Youth A in the hallway as he took the medication from the
first aid kit.
• Facility policy and procedures were reviewed and of note
was the section titled "Medication Administration and
Pharmaceuticals." This policy had a section specific to
over the counter medications in which it was described that
those medications "are stored in the Medical Clinic either in
a locked cabinet, locked refrigerator, or locked
pharmaceutical cart, behind a locked door."
• Safety plans authored by the facility for Youth A were
provided. Upon his return to the program on 02/01/2024 it
was planned that Youth A had restrictions on his clothing
and be provided one-on-one supervision.
o In addition, documentation was provided that
showed coverage of one-on-one supervision from
this date onwards, including the date of 02/05/2024
when the second incident occurred.
• Medical documentation from the Detroit Medical Center
was provided and no additional concerns other than proper
mental health treatment and safety planning for Youth A in
the facility’s programming.
Analysis Through on-site inspections, interviews with youth and staff and
documentation reviewed there was evidence found to support a
rule violation regarding the facility not following their own policy on
the storage of medications.
Technical Assistance provided:
• Prompt, complete and organized responses to
documentation requests for investigations is required
and the facility is advised to consider procedures to
allow for this to occur easily.
• Consideration should be given to common classroom
and office items such as loose staples that could easily
be used for self-harm by an escalated youth.
Conclusion Violation Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
